video_title: Is Elden Ring Nightreign ACTUALLY Good?
comment_text:
I got dev copy of the game and played it for over 15h and... Dude I love your content but you're one of the least trustworthy people to review this game;P 
(And I mean it in... a nice way) 
You're VERY biased towards From. I get it. I love them as well. 
But Nightreign is VERY clunky. Level design is poor, loot system is NOTHING that other rogue lites haven't done better and there's not even an attempt to make an interesting story (like in Hades for example)
Nightreign is a safe game. There's not a single innovation that game introduces. And battle royale machanic on top is just janky as hell - especially when playing with a team of randoms.
So yeah - I love From but I'm tired of giving excuses just because they are From Software. For me the game is just ok(ish) but nowhere near as good as their other titles.

video_title: Is Elden Ring Nightreign ACTUALLY Good?
comment_text:
26:45 I'm sorry, but it's a full 40$ game which already reuses insane amount of assets, so I'm pretty confident that expecting more than just 1 map and 1 game mode is completely reasonable. There's plenty of cheaper games, especially indie, that has way more content made specifically for the game and not mostly reused from previous titles. I think it's more than fair to expect more than that from a big, triple A developer like Fromsoft, especially since Elden Ring was such a massive hit.

EDIT/ ‚ÄãJust to clarify my point. Neither price nor reuse is bad in isolation. I don't even mind that it was a training project for new director. Demon Souls was basically one too. The point of reusing assets is so you can cut costs and spend more time on other stuff. I'm not saying they didn't make anything new for the game, but compere to reused content, it's not that much. If the game was cheaper, like 20/30$ then lack of new content and variety would feel less bad, but if they want to charge so much for it, they had to do more with it to justify it. So yes, having few different maps, even with reused assets and more game modes would go a long way to justify it.

video_title: Is Elden Ring Nightreign ACTUALLY Good?
comment_text: I think FromSoftware needs to do something to catch up because their games become way too outdated. Elden Ring was already severely outdated in a lot of different aspects like graphics, animations, movement, camerawork, physics, combat, stealth, enemy AI, quest design, dialogues, character progression, skills etc. And from what I've seen so far, Neightreign seems like it's even less impressive. It looks like a PS3-era game with its stiff animations, weapons clipping through your armor, outdated visual effects and weightless attacks that don't even connect with enemies properly. People at FromSoftware are pretty great at creating amazing worlds with immaculate atmosphere but they fall behind in everything else, and I think it's funny how everyone seems to be ignoring that. Everyone loves to criticize Ubisoft or EA, but when FromSoftware fails to innovate or improve on their outdated game engine, no one bats an eye.

comment_text:
I‚Äôll write my opinion on it, even though it probably won‚Äôt be seen or cared for. I am not a fan of the game (haven‚Äôt played it yet to make it clear). I have nothing against the genre and I think this could be a fun game from fromsoft, if it didn‚Äôt break all sense of continuity. My first problem is the movement, why can the characters move so quickly and scale walls and crap, but the tarnished can‚Äôt? Isn‚Äôt the tarnished from Elden Ring supposed to be the strongest in the lands between? Also where did all these ‚ÄúNight Lords‚Äù come from? Why weren‚Äôt they in the OG Elden ring? If they are in a version of the lands between, why didn‚Äôt we encounter them in Elden ring? Or hear about them? Also the dark souls bosses being dragged in makes no sense lore-wise (I know the spouted some crap but it‚Äôs a weak reasoning when the director said that he added them just because he thought it would be fun), it would mean that this is either a inter-dimensional setting which would make these night lords the strongest characters seen in fromsoft, or ER and DS share a universe, which has already been stated as false in the past to my knowledge. So it just makes no sense from a lore standpoint and due to the weird movement it makes no sense from a continuity standpoint. 

TLDR: this game breaks continuity and doesn‚Äôt make much sense from a lore standpoint, it would be a great game if it wasn‚Äôt an asset flip and didn‚Äôt leech off the ER name.
reply_text: Your main complaint being "the story doesn't make sense" when you haven't played it or seen anything from its story is a nothingburger take, just saying.

video_title: Is Elden Ring Nightreign ACTUALLY Good?
comment_text: Tbh, as big a Fromsoft fanboy as I am, the beta convinced me not to buy this. I don't think I'm particularly bad at Souls games, but queueing with randoms I was only able to make it to day 2 once over about a dozen attempts. Apart from disconnects (which is totally understandable in a beta), my teammates were always either running far ahead or dilly dallying in the original drop area. Since I wasn't very familiar with the map or mechanics, I couldn't tell which one was doing the right thing, so I ended up just kind of running back and forth picking up loot and fighting basic mobs without any real goals in mind until the big day end fight killed us. I wanted to explore more, but the time limit made it basically impossible to both learn things AND beat bosses. It's interesting that you mention things becoming a bit boring when you know the optimal way to approach the map, because honestly, I think the process of learning this is kind of annoying too (at least with randos). You have no way of knowing whether your teammates are doing something clever or stupid until it either works, or doesn't. If I had a crew of people who wanted to coop with me over mic, I could imagine enjoying this. But the way it's currently set up feels really off putting for a single player.
reply_text: You can do solo runs, the difficulty scales

video_title: Is Elden Ring Nightreign ACTUALLY Good?
comment_text: A note on the no SotE enemies or bosses (barring the hippo) from what I have heard nightreign was developed later on but at the same time as elden ring base game was, so there werent any dlc enemies for them to add. The project is a way for FromSoft to teach newer developers and directors about game creation in a safer environment and give them the room to fail without a huge amount of pressure, while also letting them learn lessons on where they might or have failed. I love this approach as it gives the consumers a taste of something new while gearing up the next names for their big projects, and I believe Duskbloods is in a similar boat regarding its internal aim. FromSoft for the win again

I've been hyped for this specifically because it's experimental. Even if it's not a 10/10 FS banger, the idea of mixing up the formula in interesting ways could lead to all sorts of new ideas and it gives the devs more experience with different types of gameplay. 

I know a lot of people just want what's essentially another Dark Souls or Elden Ring, but I believe it's been stated that this game is not stopping them from working on other projects. I mean it's essentially an overhaul mod for Elden Ring so it hasn't required the same level of development as a mainline FS game.

This game feels like it's a "just for fun" side project to test out a bunch of stuff. An intermission of sorts between mainline titles. A play test for various ideas to see what they might want or not want to put in future titles.

video_title: Is Elden Ring Nightreign ACTUALLY Good?
comment_text: Speedrunners would appreciate this gameplay. I sometimes feel the slow pace of fromsoft games emasculating me. Yeah it's cool to run into a scenario knowing you have to be more thoughtful and maybe push your limits to meet the challenge but it gets tiring and sometimes boring. The openness of Nightreign lets your focus be exploring and looting rather than getting stuck in the same fight over and over. If I don't want to finish a fight, I have dozens of other options. This makes leveling up and looting the main priority and then you spend your attention on the boss. That's an ideal game loop for me. Challenging myself to explore quickly and level up as fast as possible so I can beat the boss. This makes grinding levels fun rather than a cop out for when you're not good enough to beat the boss.

comment_text: a little thing you didn't discover, because you wouldn't expect it: there's actually 3 different animations for getting intercepted by springtrap as a survivor trying to use the security doors: one where he comes at you from a side door, which is when springtrap teleports to the door you're coming from, while he comes from a door you're NOT going to, or if he starts his teleport when you're already in the cutscene. two, is when hes mid teleport and you start the cutscene, where he will be standing right in front of the door you're going through when it opens. 3, is when he follows you through a security door (ex, you're in chase and try to escape by taking door 7, and he follows you through it), with an animation of you turning around and he comes from behind.
reply_text: Is there not one when you are checking the cameras? The power mentions that he can catch survivors when they're in cams

video_title: New Killer "Springtrap" from FNAF | Dead by Daylight PTB
comment_text: Am I the only one who feels a little disappointed...? I was praying we would get something super unique for how much they hyped up this chapter plus how big the license is, and yet we just get a bunch of mechanics we have already seen before.. The mori looks stiff and weird, and the map, while still cool, definitely doesnt have a lot of the iconic FNaF stuff that you would expect a FNaF map to have (It doesnt even have a security office. The FIVE NIGHTS AT FREDDY'S MAP doesnt have a SECURITY OFFICE. How did they even come to that?) The power plays like a short range huntress, and the AOE of the axe in the environment does very little to change the killer enough to feel mechanically different from Huntresses hatchet throwing gameplay... Im genuinely disappointed with the chapter, I have been waiting for 6 years for this killer and when we finally get him its just recycled gameplay elements.. Im genuinely sad this is what the year long hyped up chapter turned out to be.

video_title: New Killer "Springtrap" from FNAF | Dead by Daylight PTB
comment_text: In my personal opinion, there isn't a good enough incentive for survivors to be using the door cameras as is. While the interactive element is cool, it's pretty useless, so I can see optimal gameplay against him being to ignore those entirely and just treat his doors like lockers with dredge. What they should do is give him an extremely small terror radius like myers, and make revealing him on cameras give him a normal terror radius, like a ghost face reveal. Having a projectile killer with a small terror radius can be an extreme threat, and so creating this scenario where survivors need to check the cameras in order reveal him before he sneaks up on someone would make his ability much more fun and actually usable. If they did that, or something similar, this would be the perfect fnaf killer

video_title: Nintendo 64 ‚Äì Nintendo Classics: Features Update
comment_text: People: rewind works by storing an entire dump of the N64's RAM for every frame that you got back. So 10 seconds for a 30 FPS game would be 300 x 4 (or 8) MB, which means it uses 1.2GB or 2.4GB (depending on if its an expansion pack game). That's why this cannot work on Switch 1.
reply_text: You can clearly tell they are not storing each frame's memory, but at time intervals (and only a fixed number of them) which would use A LOT less memory. These Switch 2 features are only to prop up the Switch 2 making it more desirable.

reply_text: (One place you can get srt's from is OpenSubtitles. That's usually where I grab them from.)

video_title: Closed captions on DVDs are getting left behind
comment_text: I recall being able to utilize European teletext on some of my old VHS recordings because of the whole "stick data into the vertical blanking interval" thing.
reply_text: You really need an S-VHS recording to do that. People have extracted Teletext from VHS tapes but it requires looking at multiple copies of the data to extract the teletext signal from the noise.

video_title: Closed captions on DVDs are getting left behind
comment_text: Thanks for posting this - it fits at an intersection between accessibility and backwards compatibility, both of which are things the tech industry is not good at right now.  One thing I'd add though is that accessibility features like closed captioning are helpful not just to the deaf and hard of hearing.  Closed captions are a perfect example of this - if you imagine watching a TV at a loud bar or watching a video on your phone on the bus or while your child is asleep, closed captions help you, too!
reply_text: Not to mention, laying in bed at 3am next to your sleeping wife, watching you tube videos with the sound off.

comment_text:
Taking a quick look, it seems that DVDs actually have two different sets of EIA captions available, EIA-608 and EIA-708, which could explain the differences that VLC is having. That said, there's a few semi-dedicated programs for extracting the data and converting it to one of the caption formats VLC likes a lot better. 
Oh, and the 4k Blu-ray and Play Station both seem to be moving the text around appropriately, they just have the entire thing scaled down to the point that it doesn't look it on first glance.
reply_text: ‚Äã@@unwiredben yes, though a DVD having both is a likely culprit for the issues VLC has in showing the same captions you see. If it tries to extract both or if the 708 version is not properly edited (while the 608 is, being happy to display through a DVD player), it could cause issues

video_title: Closed captions on DVDs are getting left behind
comment_text: Speaking of bit rot, I recently got into "old school" LTO magnetic tape drives after I was horrified to learn that SSD's and HDD's experience bit rot as well. That's a whole other rabbit hole that I think would be perfect for a Technology Connections video. The tapes have much higher durability than anything else out there, as well as having INSANE dollar-per-GB storage (as little as $80 for a 45 terabyte cartridge!), which is why they are still used heavily for backups and data-hoarding. Granted, they have their own crazy oddities and extremely high barriers to entry.
reply_text: If you'd like to do a video on it, I can probably lend you my USB LTO-9 drive, which are difficult to find, and very pricey. One of the interesting bits about LTO drives revolves around the SAS interface, which the vast majority of PC's don't have, hence the USB convenience of my drive; although my drive does also support SAS as well.

video_title: Closed captions on DVDs are getting left behind
comment_text: FYI the CC data is still being output via the HDMI since the CC is part of the image but the reason you do not see it when hooked up to HDMI is because the TV's CC decoder is only being used on the RF/AV inputs and not the HDMI inputs. So the issue is with the TV, not the players that you are incorrectly blaming.

video_title: Closed captions on DVDs are getting left behind
comment_text:
FFmpeg maintainer here, and the details behind the caption decoding issues you're seeing in VLC are complex and horrific. They largely stem from how the EIA-608 caption format expects text to be laid out in a monospace grid onscreen, which isn't really how the text rendering stacks used for modern subtitling work (this is probably why changing the font caused problems on those Sony players); beyond that, the behavior can just end up pretty complex, and there's no convenient public-domain corpus of sample files for open-source software developers to test against. These kinds of issues also affect the Japanese (ARIB) and European (Teletext) formats to varying extents. These days, a lot of the focus ends up being on converting the text into modern Unicode text formats, styled using modern techniques, so direct rendering of the legacy formats hasn't had as much attention lately. If anybody reading this has some badly-behaved samples and wants to contribute, patches to improve the decoding and rendering behavior are definitely welcome, though!

One small correction: at 1:49 and 14:53, you say the players are "decoding" the captions, which isn't quite right. The captioning data embedded in the MPEG-2 bitstream (or H.264 in some more recent contexts) is the exact same format found on line 21 of the NTSC TV signal, so the player doesn't actually have to decode anything! It just takes the caption data from the current frame (or field) of video and sends it straight out on its analog output, completely unmodified.

comment_text:
I'm hearing impaired. Let me tell you that closed captionning is just totally awesome. Like, TOTALLY AWESOME. There are even some conventions that are not carried out into subtitles and that makes me sad. The last time I saw some of theses conventions was on a Tom Scott video with multiple guest and it made the experience so much more enjoyable. Examples of things forgotten :
-Placing the subtitle under the person talking (as said in video). Most often it is quite clear, but making it crystal clear is always good.
-Writting in italic when the person talking is not on screen
-Changing the subtitle color depending on who talks (I'm not sure it is a CC thing, but in France it was used like that, but there is a video of you about this I think).

Anyway, at this time, youtube auto-subtitles in english is almost perfect and allows me to watch videos with no subtitles with no trouble. I can't say the same about french auto-subtitles which makes me kinda sad. Bizarely, my sister, who also share the same problem is mostly fine with french subtitles. Which indicates that despite being the same final issue (not understanding) there is like multiple ways of not understanding things. The more you know.
reply_text: I know in most languages it doesn't happen much, but Japanese CCs will write the name of who is talking before the line when they are off-screen or it's not obvious because they are multiple characters. And they even try to avoid spoilers when possible when you aren't supposed to know who is speaking

video_title: Closed captions on DVDs are getting left behind
comment_text:
As someone who watches foreign TV shows and has an Emby server set up, I have invested LOTS of time getting subtitles/CC working correctly. Emby has a few hang-ups when it comes to rasterized subtitles, so I am typically glad to see CC on a DVD because MakeMKV automatically converts CC to text based subtitles that are supported through all of Emby's various playback options (you have to separate them from the MKV for Emby which is simple enough I made a script to do it). Most of the time I have spent is trying to OCR rasterized subtitles into text based ones. So If anything I have been dealing with the issue in reverse.

I will say that figuring out what doesn't work with Emby is a bit of a moving target. I was shocked when I tried rasterized subtitles yesterday in the Windows Emby app and it worked without transcoding, this will save me time in the future
reply_text: You should really consider switching to Emby's successor, Jellyfin.  It supports burning bitmap-based subtitle formats (VOBSUB, PGS, SSA, etc) into the video stream through transcoding, and even recently introduced an experimental PGS renderer for some clients that will draw the bitmap subtitles without inducing transcoding on the server.

video_title: Closed captions on DVDs are getting left behind
comment_text: I worked for Sony (Broadcast and Professional) in the late nineties, on DVD authoring software (Windows based). I learnt so much about the DVD architecture and its specifications.  But some features like "Choice Points" and "Angles" were lost on the mainstream because they cost movie production companies too much to implement. An example is the "Choice Point" feature, where as a movie viewer you could choose the outcome of a scene.  This was shown off  in one or two movies, but they didn't do well. So that feature died a death.  Likewise, "Angles" were only used by the "adult entertainment" industry (you can imagine why), and that didn't last long either. Shame, I put so much effort into these features in our software.
reply_text: There are some DVDs utilizing angles out there, particularly anime, you can switch between Japanese, English or no credits. I know there's more, but don't have any examples that come to mind right now.

video_title: Closed captions on DVDs are getting left behind
comment_text:
Okay. I was a good boy. I waited all the way until you got to your thesis in minute two or so. 

Subtitles are a creature of the DVD disc architecture. Closed captioning is EIA508 or 608 stuff that's buried in the video stream, and that's what that symbol tells you that you have.

It is entirely possible, and actually likely, that source material that old was never subtitled, and that's why the subtitle button is not getting you anything.

Subtitling and captioning are aimed at different audiences which is one of the reasons why subtitles don't always match what's being said on the screen.

Source: there's an entire book about this stuff, and I spent the $50 to buy it 10 years ago when I worked at a deaf services company.
reply_text: Why they're not being displayed on the HDMI output, that I can't tell you. But the stuff you're looking at there is absolutely closed captioning data, not subtitle data.

comment_text:
So, VLC has some options for customizing the display of Closed Captions, which might improve the experience for you, but oh boy are they buried deep. In the Preferences dialog, you need to pick "All" under the "Show settings" dialog, then under Video > Subtitles / OSD > Text renderer, you can change the font, size, and style of the captions to something better suited for it. I think a lot of the problem is that the default size plus the selection of Courier New for the monospace font used for CC  makes it so the positioning logic doesn't work at all well for CC streams. I have it set to a proportional font and that seems to work a lot better. A monospace font with a narrower character width would probably also work all right.

Note that these settings are shared with the rendering for SRT-based subtitles I believe, so changing them probably also affects the rendering of those.
reply_text:
@@ddttranslator You are talking about subtitles NOT Line21 CC.
VLC does not support CEA-608 closed captions.

video_title: Closed captions on DVDs are getting left behind
comment_text: The captions on the last Blu-ray player are still moving left to right, just much less so. I'd be willing to bet their positioning data is an absolute value based on a 720 wide display. The player is upscaling the output to 1920 wide but not scaling the caption position with it.
reply_text: @@andrewwinfield8592 Probably still simpler than all the positioning shenanigans around SSA/ASS subtitles, where different versions of subtitling software need to be detected and different behavior implemented to have consistent behavior from what the author wanted, and even then there's other issues that you just have to toggle options until it looks right.  Then HDR has added an extra fun layer on top of subtitle coloring, especially when the coloring is intended to be part of the video itself as something like a mask or something over some sign or something.

video_title: Closed captions on DVDs are getting left behind
comment_text: I went into a little bit of a closed caption rabbit hole because I figured this couldn't be that difficult of a problem to solve for manufacturers. It turns out that Comcast (yes, really) provides a free, open source, Apache licensed reference extractor for closed caption data from MPEG video. It's even built to work with ffmpeg.

video_title: I put down a deposit on this car - 2025 Volkswagen ID Buzz
comment_text:
We test drove it, it was uncomfortable for passengers.

There were few cupholders and no storage space for any kid stuff.  That "hidey hole" he showed is the only one.  There are no pockets in the doors, no cupholders for the middle seat, and the ones up front are small and cant hold a standard thermal coffee cup. 

The things that Linus was mentioning about the touch things on the steering wheel activating when you were driving were very annoying. 

For as large of a vehicle as it was, it felt cramped and the view was not as clear in all directions as I would have expected for as much glass as there is. The pillars are VERY wide.  I would have preferred more thinner pillars. 

Lastly its VERY HEAVY and you feel it, what Linus was talking about with the jerk to start and jerk to slow down is very noticeable.

We were very excited about this, we signed up 4 years ago when they first announced this and checked it out at the auto show.  We test drove it twice to give it a second chance, we aren't Linus so we don't get a week, we just got to drive around for 10 minutes with the sales person but overall we were disappointed.  

We were so hyped for it and it just let us down, $80-90,000 CAD $60-70,000 USD (before taxes)we expected more drivability and creature comforts.
reply_text: You won't get thinner pillars, that's just the deal with modern safety.

comment_text: No tactile physical buttons = instant garbage.

video_title: I put down a deposit on this car - 2025 Volkswagen ID Buzz
comment_text:
Every time I hear Linus talk about cruise control, I end up questioning if I'm human. He always explains how it lets him pay more attention to the road‚Äîespecially in school zones‚Äîbecause he doesn't need to look at the speedometer. Meanwhile, I've never looked at my speedometer for more then a fraction of a second. Plus, if there are other cars on the road, than I know how fast to go based on their speed (and the distance between me and the car in front of me). However, even without other cars, I know how fast I'm going without looking at the speedometer. But, how is that possible? By feeling the small vibrations in the car, and knowing how they change as the vehicle speed changes. In other words, through experience of knowing the car. Of course, this does take time to develop, and the speedometer is handy for dialing that in. However, I would still know an approximate speed (within 5mph of accurate) during the very first time I'm in the car. How? By using my eyes and ears. Knowing how fast you are going by judging the time it takes your vehicle to travel along the road is an important skill. Plus, if you lower the driver's window by a small amount (an inch or so) then you'll hear the wind begin to change drastically as you hit 40mph. Of course, you don't want to go anywhere near that speed in a school zone. But, it's just another bit of important info that can let you know how fast you're going.

So, am I just an oddball? Am I just some super "god tier" level driver‚Äîusing inhuman skills to gauge speed without a speedometer? Does Linus really have no idea how fast he's going if he doesn't stare at the speedometer? Maybe he's never considered these things, or never been told about them? I just don't know anymore. Maybe I'm not human, or maybe my experience is common. Any info to help me know the answers would be greatly appreciated. Thanks!
reply_text: You can get a ticket here for being even 3 km/h over the limit and will have people riding your ass if you are 1km below. I just don't feel like thinking about it - LS

video_title: I put down a deposit on this car - 2025 Volkswagen ID Buzz
comment_text:
As someone who has been driving the 2023 VW ID Buzz for almost 2 years, I agree more or less with everything Linus says here. I am able to get the car over 500km on a summer day, but I assume that 4WD takes a lot of the range of the 2025 model.
The space is fantastic, but the car is massive, so expect a lot of sidling around the car in parking lots. The turn radius is incredible and the overall driving is pretty, but I can't deny that the touch interface drives me absolutely insane. The infotainment system is also relatively slow (no Tesla for sure), and the lack of an easy shortcut to music is a mind boggling decision.

Overall a pretty good car with a few things that grinds my gears. The price is also quite high, and if it was up to me, I probably would have bought a Tesla instead.

video_title: I put down a deposit on this car - 2025 Volkswagen ID Buzz
comment_text:
Something I didn't see you mention here, which may be of HUGE interest to Linus, is the complete lack of cupholders for anyone other than the front occupants. Nothing in the middle, nothing in the back. If you have kids back there with a juice or a drink from mcdonalds or whatever, it is ending up on the floor either in the cup or out of it at some point. It won't be long until stepping into the back seats is gonna feel an awful lot like stepping into your seat at the movie theater. Sticky floors. 

Also 13:15 nice cameo there. 

Best people mover I have ever been in was a chrysler pacifica from around 2020 or so. It was extremely comfortable and luxurious for what it was, competent power with the V6(not fast by any means, but not slow), and it had AWD. I am not a dad but I was a passenger with one driving on a small road trip during a snowtorm here in Ontario and there were no problems with traction or getting stuck or anything, and we drove something like 500km with just filling up before we left. Wasn't bad at all. Still very-mini-van-y of course but if I had to move people around regularly that would probably be my pick. Not cheap, though but the build quality was great. Possibly because its made in Canada.

video_title: I put down a deposit on this car - 2025 Volkswagen ID Buzz
comment_text:
I absolutely adore the ID Buzz. The issue though is that in the American market, at least the US market, you HAVE to have the panoramic sunroof with crystal shading, and a plethora of computers all the way back including their haptic buttons. The Buzz is outpricing a TON of people who would absolutely love to have one. Providing the ID Buzz without that panoramic crystal shaded roof? Removing some of those computers throughout the machine? They could easily drop the price of the thing by 10-15k. 

There are a lot of no choice options that drive the price up in the American market, compared to the European market, and it is already leading to slower than projected sales, ESPECIALLY with the tariff garbage in the US. 

I want to love this car, but the fact that it is out of my price range specifically because of expensive items packed into the base model of the vehicle? I'll be waiting for re-sale instead.

Haptic touch controls are fidgety and shitty, and the panoramic moonroof add SO Much money onto the cost of this car.

video_title: What if you used a flamethrower as a snowblower?
comment_text: I'm an AC and refrigerator Technician. I often have to defrost evaporator coils.  Hot and even lukewarm water works better than hot air. The air just reflects back but water seeps in.
reply_text: If you perfectly sealed your air blower to the coil, the water would still be ~4X more effective due to heat capacity per mass, and of course the ease of moving the same mass when 1000X denser.

video_title: What if you used a flamethrower as a snowblower?
comment_text: 1:12 Melting one gram of snow takes 335 joules of energy, while heating a gram of water up by 1¬∞C only takes 4.18 joules. That means it takes the same amount of energy to melt water as to bring it four-fifths of the way to boiling afterwards!
reply_text:
Mind you, the transition from liquid to gas (the point at which boiling Actually happens) Also takes a lot of energy, just like the transition from solid to liquid, though I couldn't tell you exactly how much without looking it up.
And if you get the combination of pressure and material right, you can skip the liquid stage entirely and go straight from solid to gas.

video_title: What if you used a flamethrower as a snowblower?
comment_text:
1:04 Lasers are also inefficient at clearing snow, due to the high albedo of snow. The light just bounces off it.
If you used visible light, you would only be about 10% efficient, with the other 90% blinding you and your neighbors. Other wavelengths might work better, but it's still a bad way to transmit energy into a white material.
reply_text: snow's albedo isn't high for every wavelength. you've just gotta choose a wavelength it absorbs (like infer red).
